text:
LARRY MIZE: It doesn't get
more exciting in golf for me
than that day right there.

- For as long as
he can remember,

he'd always wanted
to be a golfer.

Growing up in Augusta,
how could you not?

LARRY MIZE: You know, I can
remember some things with dad.

It was a big influence
of me and my golf.

We'd chip balls
in the front yard.

He was always harping
on the short game.

And, you know, I think
it served me well.

- Before long, young Larry
Mize was working at Augusta
National, home of the masters.

LARRY MIZE: I was
loving it then.

You know, I was on
the third scoreboard.

And you'd climb up the ladder
and put the numbers on there.

And you'd have the
little windows.

You'd open the window and
peek out, and try and watch
the play on the third hole.
And as a kid, you were just--

you were in hog
heaven out there.
Yeah.

- But who could have
known that one day,

he'd go on to win
the whole thing?

In 1987, in a playoff with Seve
Ballesteros and Greg Norman,

Larry Mize chipped in
from around 100 feet

to claim the green jacket, one
of the most dramatic finishes

ever seen at this
famous old golf course.

LARRY MIZE: People say, when
did you know it was going in?
Not till it went in.
I mean, it looked good.

But, I hit it, and
it looked great.
I'm frozen.
Just watching it.
Frozen.

And, you know, it goes in the
hole, and I throw my club up.

And I ran around
screaming like a madman.
Just total, total elation.

- What was the noise
like when it went in?

LARRY MIZE: Oh it was
kind of deafening.
It really was.

David, my oldest son,
was a week shy of a year.

And poor thing, it
scared him to death.
He's crying.
Bonnie's saying, it's OK.
It's just dad.
- That was 30 years ago.

And he can remember it
like it was yesterday.

LARRY MIZE: It's going
to be a new thing
when I've turned to page two.
Let's see here.

The glue is not
holding up too well.
- It's 30-year-old glue.
LARRY MIZE: Exactly.

- Whether it's in a
scrapbook or in his own mind,
the memories are indelible.

And he'll do whatever it
takes to preserve them.

LARRY MIZE: And I think
that says it all there.

I'm screaming and I'm
just total excitement.

Just pure excitement
right there.
LARRY MIZE: Yeah.

Norman can't believe Mize's
impossible shot went in.
LARRY MIZE: Right.

Yeah, I mean, he
wasn't expecting that.
And who could expect it?

But, you know, in
golf, you always

have to expect the
worst from your opponent
so that you're ready for it.

But, it is hard to expect
me to make it from there.

- How often do you think
you've seen it on TV?
LARRY MIZE: Not enough.

You know, one mistake I
realized, looking back,

I would have probably watched
it more and relived it more.

I probably-- I tried
to go beyond it

and continue to move on and
stuff a little too quickly.

And that's what I
tell anybody now.
Savor this, enjoy it.

- So you never
played a ball that's
landed anywhere near there?

LARRY MIZE: No, never been
really close to that spot
that I remember.

I mean, that's the only
way I'd play it again
is if I hit it over there.

If I hit it there in the
practice round, I'd move it.
I wouldn't play it.
- Really?

LARRY MIZE: No, it's
just such a great memory.

I don't want to ruin
it by having, oh yeah.

I had another shot from there
and this is what happened.

You know, I did it
when I needed to.

And I want to keep
that memory pure.

And it's been
great for 30 years.
